metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Leaf area index of Daman Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Daman superstation in the middle reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from July 22 to September 5 in 2021. The site (100.376° E, 38.853°N) was located in the maize surface, near Zhangye city in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. There are 3 observation samples, each of which is about 30m×30m in size, and the latitude and longitude are (100.374°E, 38.855°N), (100.371° E, 38.854°N), (100.369°E, 38.854°N). Four sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 5 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid regions is the use of the LAINet wireless sensor network. This system automatically collects light data from multiple nodes daily and processes it to calculate LAI, adjusting for weather variations through a 5-day moving average.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting ecological data in inland river basins of arid and semiarid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in collecting ecological data in these regions is the ecological environment degradation, which includes the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes long-term observations from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems from 2012 to 2021, which cover energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. This dataset is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the 'LAI (Leaf Area Index) wireless sensor network (LAINet)' used for in data collection?
Definition.Answer: The 'LAI (Leaf Area Index) wireless sensor network (LAINet)' is used to automatically collect daily and hourly light data from each node to calculate the Leaf Area Index (LAI). It processes raw data to compute daily LAI values, identify and fill invalid data, apply a 5-day moving average to minimize weather impacts on LAI calculations, and derive the average of multiple nodes for final observation values in a given subarea.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'eddy covariance system' in collecting data in oasis–desert ecosystem research?
Definition.Answer: The 'eddy covariance system' is significant in collecting data in oasis–desert ecosystem research because it provides half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is essential for understanding long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane exchanges in these ecosystems. This method is part of a comprehensive suite of observational datasets aimed at supporting ecological security and sustainable development in oasis areas.

Definition.Question: What does 'data processing and quality control procedure' involve in the context of hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of hydrometeorological data collection, 'data processing and quality control procedure' involves the stages of data collection, processing, and archiving and sharing. This includes observing various parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and other meteorological data from automatic weather stations, and ensuring the data's accuracy and reliability through systematic processing and quality control measures.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems improve our understanding of hydrometeorological processes in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating data from both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems provides a comprehensive view of hydrometeorological processes, which includes energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, alongside auxiliary data like soil and vegetation parameters. This integration helps in recognizing oasis–desert interactions and informs strategies for ecological protection and sustainable development.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying data patterns from the long-term observational datasets could indicate challenges faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, such as ecological degradation?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term data patterns may reveal trends of river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and increased desertification, highlighting ecological challenges in arid and semiarid inland river basins. Such patterns can be crucial for understanding the impact of these challenges on ecological stability and guiding mitigation efforts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of maintaining ecological balance in oasis-desert systems, especially regarding data collection and long-term monitoring?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges like river drying, vegetation degradation, desertification, and dust storms. These challenges are particularly acute in regions along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to have a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A quantitative understanding is crucial to achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development. It also helps protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, emphasizing the need for long-term observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the need for diverse data collection methods in studying oasis-desert areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity of the oasis-desert system, which involves energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, necessitates varied data collection methods such as eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations, and supplementary vegetation and soil parameter data, to comprehensively understand the ecosystem dynamics and interactions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of employing wireless sensor networks for leaf area index data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using wireless sensor networks for leaf area index data collection can enhance the efficiency of data acquisition and processing, allowing for continuous and high-resolution monitoring of vegetation dynamics. This can improve understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems, contributing to sustainable development and ecological security in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might long-term observational datasets impact the understanding of energy and water vapor exchanges in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets provide critical insights into the seasonal and interannual variability of energy and water vapor exchanges, thereby deepening the understanding of the interactions between oasis and desert systems. This can aid in devising strategies to maintain ecological balance and ensure sustainable development in arid and semiarid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating multiple sources of hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters in oasis–desert studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple sources of hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters can offer a comprehensive view of the ecosystem processes, thereby enabling more accurate modeling and analysis of the oasis–desert interactions. This integration helps address challenges related to ecological degradation and supports efforts towards achieving carbon neutrality and ecological stability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and techniques are commonly used to measure leaf area index (LAI) in arid and semiarid regions, and how do these methods ensure data accuracy and reliability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Leaf Area Index (LAI) in arid and semiarid regions is measured using a wireless sensor network called LAINet. This instrument automatically collects light data from each node hourly, and software processes these to compute daily LAI values. The data is further refined by identifying and filling invalid values and applying a 5-day moving average to minimize weather-related impacts. The final processed data, stored in Level3 format, represents the mean LAI values across multiple nodes within an observation plot.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in the quality control and dissemination of long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for quality control and dissemination of long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert ecosystems include data collection from various sensors, processing to ensure data quality and accuracy, and archiving for future use. The datasets, covering parameters such as energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, and auxiliary data, are shared through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, ensuring accessibility for research and ecological management purposes.

Enablement.Question: What technologies enable the collection and processing of leaf area index (LAI) data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of leaf area index (LAI) data in arid and semi-arid regions is enabled by technologies such as the LAINet, a wireless sensor network that automatically records light data at each node daily. The LAINet software processes this raw data to calculate LAI, performs invalid value identification and filling, and applies a 5-day moving average to mitigate weather effects.

Enablement.Question: How do long-term observational datasets enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets enhance understanding by providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are faced in maintaining the ecological balance in inland river basins of arid and semi-arid areas, and how do datasets help address these challenges?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in maintaining ecological balance include the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. Datasets help address these challenges by providing critical data on environmental and hydrometeorological conditions, enabling better management and conservation strategies.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in maintaining long-term observations for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological challenges such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of vegetation, and desertification, which can complicate long-term observations necessary for understanding these exchanges.

Expectation.Question: Why could the integration of hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters be crucial for datasets in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, which involves integrating hydrometeorological data with vegetation and soil parameters to protect ecological stability and support socioeconomic development.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Wireless sensor networks like LAINet are effective for collecting leaf area index data in arid regions as they allow for continuous and automated data collection at multiple nodes, providing detailed temporal and spatial information that can be processed into various levels for analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges of maintaining accurate long-term datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining accurate long-term datasets in oasis–desert systems is challenging due to ecological degradation, climate variability, and the need for consistent data processing and quality control procedures to ensure reliable data over time.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in acquiring reliable data from the inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, increased land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which complicate data acquisition and reliability.

Assertion.Answer: Datasets integrate these parameters by supplementing energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, collected from various stations and processed with quality control procedures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to acquire leaf area index measurements in arid regions and how these methods account for environmental variability.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for leaf area index measurements in arid regions include using a wireless sensor network (LAINet) that automatically gathers hourly light data at multiple canopy nodes. The raw data (Level0) is processed using LAINet software to calculate daily LAI (Level1), and further refined by identifying and filling invalid values, and applying a 5-day sliding average to mitigate weather-induced variability (Level2). The averaged values of multiple nodes provide the final observation for each sub-area (Level3).

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the main challenges faced when collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert ecosystems, particularly in the context of climate change.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation degradation, intensified land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are exacerbated by climate change, which necessitates long-term monitoring to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. Inland river basins like the Tarim River basin face similar crises, impacting data collection efforts.
